persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

places.name: River Thames
places.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

places.name: Iceland
places.description: A Nordic island country between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

persons.name: JamesSmithson
persons.description: Born Jacques-Louis Macie in Paris; became James Louis Macie upon naturalizing to Britain and in 1800 adopted his father's original surname of Smithson. Wealthy natural son of the Duke of Nothumberland. Proprietor of the Royal Institution who wrote on chemistry. Bequeathed his money to the United States to found the Smithsonian Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

places.name: Iceland
places.description: A Nordic island country between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

places.name: Bovey Formation (Devon)
places.description: The Bovey Formation in Devon contains lignite, a poor brown coal with a visibly woody structure.

places.name: Glasgow
places.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

places.name: Teesdale
places.description: Teesdale is a dale, or valley, in northern England.

places.name: Alston Moor
places.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

places.name: Staffa
places.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

places.name: County Antrim
places.description: A county in north-eastern Northern Ireland.

places.name: Giant's Causeway
places.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

places.name: Mount Etna
places.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

places.name: Durham, England
places.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

places.name: Derbyshire
places.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

places.name: Northumberland
places.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: GregoryWatt
persons.description: Youngest son of James Watt. Lodged with Davy's mother in Penzance during the winter of 1797-8 and became close friends with Davy.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: Gregory Watt

persons.name: JamesWatt
persons.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

persons.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
persons.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

persons.name: Johann FriedrichBlumenbach
persons.description: Professor of Medicine at Göttingen University. Race theorist who applied comparative anatomy to classification of human races. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
persons.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

persons.name: GeorgePaul
persons.description: Sir George Onesiphorus Paul, 2nd Baronet was an English prison reformer and philanthropist.

places.name: Siberia
places.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

persons.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
persons.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

persons.name: WilliamWhiston
persons.description: English (unorthodox) theologian, historian, natural philosopher, and mathematician. A leading figure in promoting the ideas of Isaac Newton whom he succeeded as Lucasian Professor.
